description:
Brevundimonas faecalis is a species of gram-negative, aerobic, non-spore-forming bacteria that belongs to the genus Brevundimonas. It is a rod-shaped bacterium, typically measuring approximately 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 0.8-2.0 μm in length.

Brevundimonas faecalis is considered an environmental bacterium, as it has been isolated from various sources, including fecal samples of humans and animals. It is known to be a slow-growing bacterium and can thrive in nutrient-rich environments.

Phenotypically, Brevundimonas faecalis is characterized by its ability to produce catalase and oxidase enzymes, and it can utilize a variety of carbohydrates as carbon sources. Genetically, the species is differentiated from other Brevundimonas species based on its unique 16S rRNA gene sequence.

The ecological role and potential clinical significance of Brevundimonas faecalis are still under investigation, as more research is needed to understand its prevalence, distribution, and potential interactions with other microorganisms or host organisms.
